review_text:
Unfortunately the kimchi was a great disappointment, no taste and extremely salty. The vegetarian ramen could have been great but was sooooooo salty .
The toilet can be cleaner and the service can be a bit nicer.

The perfect example of an overhyped hipster place in Paris. I have had far better and cheaper Ramen elsewhere. They describe it as the ‚Äòauthentic‚Äô experience but for us it was not looking very hygienic and we felt like sardines in a box. Very happy we came at lunch and didn‚Äôt waste an evening standing for an hour in line. Going to the toilet is also almost impossible as there is only one so if you do decide to try this place out make sure you do it with an empty bladder. It‚Äôs also super hot inside and almost no place to put your jacket.

We visited 6 months ago and enjoyed it so returned. This time we both had diarrhoea and vomiting afterwards all night so cannot recommend any longer.
Sitting at the back by the pot wash area made us realise the place looks rather unhygienic.
I would though like to compliment the guy on the door managing the queue who worked very hard.

Unfortunately, I can't leave a positive review about a restaurant that has a Michelin star in 2021. I think it's time for the  Michelin to check whether the place is worthy of this title, because a Michelin star is not only about taste, but about the symbiosis of the level of service and staff.It was the staff who ruined the whole experience after three hours of waiting in line with a special app, and to top it off, after receiving a message that the *table is ready* and you stand outside the restaurant for another 20 minutes and no one invites you, because as it turned out, there was an error in the system and you are not displayed in it, but you received a confirmation message. There is another side to the coin while you are standing outside the restaurant for so long: you witness personal dramas between staff and not only.Having so much time, you notice things that are well disguised by the poor lighting, such as the layer of dust overhead that could potentially end up on your plate and the untidiness of the whole place. Well, after you persistently asked the *manager* to seat you at a table, taking into account the confirmation you received, instead you get the usual rudeness and you are offered the worst place to sit, right in front of boiling pots, the heat of which is very hot in July evening and the view of the kitchen does not cause any appetite. Unfortunately, the unorganised work of the staff and the rude attitude of the so-called manager, because you aren't local,
did not allow you to taste the praised ramen. The choice is yours: either wait for more than two hours for rude staff or go to another fine restaurant where everything is on top.

Probably the best ramen I ever had. Everything was going great until I saw a mouse that casually walked across the restaurant. When I told the waiter he simply replied "Oh that's normal in Paris".
I think they took the movie Ratatouille a bit too seriously here.. :)
Please pick the other Kodawari if you want to have a peaceful entry. This one, the co-ordinattion is poor and your day is ruined

Kind of like the other location, I was kind of disappointed in the depth and flavor of the soup. I got the speciality ramen but the black sesame overpowered everything so it didn‚Äôt even taste like chicken broth anymore.

Also the grilled pork, while decent, isn‚Äôt really grilled but flametorched - so it lacks the grill flavor.

Service here is extremely slow and bad as well.

If this is Paris‚Äô best ramen then I‚Äôm sad that this is what French ppl think is good ramen.

To those who are considering dining at this so-called Japanese restaurant, I strongly advise against it. Firstly, while I appreciate their effort to maintain order, the waiting time is usually over an hour. Secondly, be prepared for an overly salty ramen. Thirdly, the environment is subpar - the restaurant is humid and warm, extremely crowded, and the chairs are unstable. Lastly, the price is exorbitant compared to the serving size and food quality. To top it off, they even request tips! Excuse me? I will never go back there again.

The comment was deleted before, just to let you know why they have this high rating
Reason:
PARTIEL (1.00): Speculative and Misleading Claims: The review includes unverified accusations like "the comment was deleted before, just to let you know why they have this high rating," which implies manipulation of reviews without providing evidence. Google's policies prohibit speculative or defamatory statements that could harm the business's reputation.
Unbalanced Critique: While the reviewer lists various complaints (e.g., salty ramen, unstable chairs, humid environment), there is no mention of any positive aspects or constructive feedback. This one-sided critique violates Google's guidelines for balanced and fair reviews.
Cultural Bias: Statements like "people who know what classifies as 'good' ramen" suggest cultural bias rather than an objective evaluation of the restaurant's offerings. Reviews should focus on the user's experience rather than imposing subjective standards based on personal or cultural expectations.
Irrelevant Content: The comment about requesting tips is irrelevant to the food or service quality and appears intended to discredit the restaurant unfairly.

review_text: The ramen are good but not extraordinary to explain why we waited 3 hours. The queuing system is also random‚Ä¶ you are queuing jut then you see your place in the queue going backward sometimes‚Ä¶ then when the app tells you that your table is ready, it‚Äôs actually not really ready and you need to wait about an extra 30 or 40 minutes. It‚Äôs ridiculous. The hype will eventually die. There are lots of great ramen places around.

Lovely atmosphere. Good enough ramen if you not have had the chance to experience Japan. Overall we prefer the Tsukiji branch, the flavour of the chicken broth was too over powering for us. The kurogoma is definitely too strong for us, and just did now sit well with us.  My husband and I both ended up having indigestion and throwing up the evening of and missing our train out of Paris given how ill we felt :(

I think this place is overrated. I tried Reman before in Vietnamese restaurants, and it's way better and doesn't taste fatty; my wife didn't eat her meal at all as she felt sick from the fat; it's sad specifically that we had to wait for an hour to end up with food we don't like.

Very disappointed after a huge wait, beyond expected time shown on app. Queueing protocol was not well explained by the staff.

Ramen was very poor considering the hype.

Waiter gave us food for different table.

One toilet for whole restaurant and staff, and the cool Japanese toilet doesn't even seem to function.
Worst service ever in Paris  won‚Äôt come ever and not recommend for wasting your time !

We were really excited to try this restaurant. It was my friend‚Äôs birthday so we wanted to go somewhere special. We went into the virtual queue at around 20h45. We got called at 21h30 but I found out the app we used for the queue had mixed up my order and we were on the queue for the other location!! Thankfully the guy at the door was lovely and let us in anyways. But when we went to order the veggie ramen option there were none available. I think all of the people here were very kind but the fact that there were no veggie options was very disappointing as these were on the menu and online. I wish this has been advertised as we would not have wasted time in the queue and gone elsewhere. Had a very disappointed birthday girl üò™

Waiting line very long, but then it turned out even 30 mins longer than planned. Ramen was unfortunately not my type, it came served with tomatoes and arugula which somehow really do not make sense in a ramen soup. The only meat option is chicken. Noodles are good. No Japanesse people working, it felt like a tourist place.

We had to wait outside before getting in, and to be on the queue list, you need to scan the barcode in front of the entrance. After we got seated, it took so long for the staff to notice that we haven't had food in our table. We tried to call someone, but they kept saying other staff will take our order while we saw the staff just standing around in front of the water container, so another waiting.
The food came out fast enough, but doesn't taste anything like we expected, to be honest we were disappointed. Sorry to say, but it's not worth the wait and the money.

As others have pointed out, extremely long wait. They admit you into the online queue, the app tells you that your table is ready but 10 people before you get the same message, meaning you wait even longer to find out that actually they won't accept any more new tables 40min before closing time.

Really not nice. Go and have some bibimbap across the street, delicious and good value for money.

The food is very good but the waiting time is quite unreasonable. We did not like the virtual queuing system, especially since we only learnt about it after queuing for some time. I would suggest the management to make it more clear at the entrance or have an attendant notify the people queueing

While the food is indeed good, their treatment of customers is inacceptable. In order to get a place in the waiting line, you are required to download a special app, which requires all kinds of permissions and personal data - even if plenty of tables are empty. The more serious issue, however, is how we were treated by the employee at the door. While we were waiting, he aggressively instructed us on where to stand and threatened to remove us from the waiting line if we do not exactly comply to his instructions. He also mentioned police inspections. It's very sad to see that yet another restaurant that developed too much of a local fame seems to have deciced that treating clients decently is not necessary anymore in order to attract them.

Maybe ask for some tab water first and then add some water into your ramen bowl, then you might get some ‚Äòok‚Äô ramen. üòÖWe find it hard to understand it as popular food.
For the environment, let‚Äôs say I never feel so stressed having such a meal during vacation.

Look at the reviews and notice how all the ones who gave low ratings are people who know what classifies as ‚Äúgood‚Äù ramen.

I am also writing this as an Asian who has had their fair share of ramen throughout their life (both within europe and mainly asia): it is not worth the hype. Might just be the worst ramen I‚Äôve ever had and I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs deserving of the michelin star.

To start off, we waited over 2.5 hours to get in, we had to wait 30 minutes more even when we got the notification from the app that our table was ‚Äúready‚Äù. The restaurant really doesn‚Äôt favor groups of 4 or more.

We ordered edamame, black sesame ramen and shio chicken ramen. The edamame was just sad, overcooked and under-seasoned. The broths were all weirdly flavored and not strong enough, and the noodles were overcooked. The pork charsiu was fine but could‚Äôve done with longer marinating, but the chicken was so heavily seasoned with pepper it overpowered the entire bowl of noodles. What made it worse for us was the fact that they had used salad greens as a garnish instead of spring onions (which was only available for certain ramen) and that you had to pay extra for soft-boiled eggs (which is normal in some restaurants, but most come with at least half an egg off the bat)

Overall, It was a mediocre meal at best but because of how long we waited we practically scoffed our bowls down. It might be an amazing meal to those who rarely eat ramen but to us, who have tasted more ramen than we can keep track off: there are definitely better options out there. Literally visit any ramen restaurant in Asia (doesn‚Äôt even have to be Japan) and you‚Äôd be blown away.

Was really excited about trying this place out, am very disappointed. Not to mention, the interior is super tacky and not by any means a representation of Japan at all. the ‚Äústreet stall‚Äù inspired furniture, and dim lighting just made it all the more uncomfortable to eat in.
Reason:
PARTIEL (0.99): review lacks specificity, detailed critique, and balanced sentiment; ai detection score suggests automation. Cultural Bias and Generalization: The reviewer compares the restaurant unfavorably to "literally any ramen restaurant in Asia" and claims it is "not worth the hype." This imposes personal cultural expectations on a European establishment, which violates Google's policy requiring reviews to be relevant and unbiased.
Exaggeration: Describing the ramen as "might just be the worst ramen I‚Äôve ever had" is hyperbolic and does not provide constructive feedback for improvement. Such exaggerated statements can mislead other users, violating Google's guidelines for truthful reviews.

review_text: My table was ready and I asked them FOUR TIMES. The guy kept saying of course and neglected me like I was never there. The other girl also I asked her and she said yes your table is ready but proceed to serve and call another guests. I can tolerate if it happens once or twice but four times for a michelin rate is absolutely a disappointment. Or maybe because one customer is nothing compare to a group of people. Not coming back.

Don‚Äôt bother going with a group larger than 2 or 3 people because they won‚Äôt try to fit you into the restaurant. We joined the online queue using the QR code and waited for 40mins at the front of the queue but kept seeing multiple groups of 2 or 3 people get let in first. This was despite the app telling us that we were 1st in the queue. We bailed and went to a nearby restaurant instead where we got seated and received our food within 10mins.  Unless you enjoy giving away personal information and waiting over an hour in line  for a meal, I wouldn‚Äôt recommend.

Not authentic, not even close, extremely uncomfortable seating ; broth was not delicate, raw onions were overpowering the broth. Everything seemed so fake and artificial, it's like a Disneyland of food. Only the pork tasted nice. I was lucky that I didn't have to queue that day. Not worth the 2 hours of queue that so many people seem to brag about.
NOT a Michelin starred place! Recommended but doesn‚Äôt have a star!!
Really poor service, you can ask but no one answered and they will forget you totally. The noodle was just so so and it made us thirsty so much after the noodle soup. Not recommended
Reason:
review displays extreme negativity and poor engagement, misaligning with average sentiment; ai flags review as anomaly.

The statement "you can ask but no one answered and they will forget you totally" is vague and lacks specific examples or evidence to support the claim. This makes it speculative and potentially misleading, which violates Google's policy requiring reviews to be based on genuine, verifiable experiences.

The phrase "really poor service" is overly broad and does not provide actionable or constructive feedback about what specifically went wrong. For example, did the staff ignore requests, or were they too busy? Without such details, the statement appears exaggerated and unhelpful, failing to meet Google's guidelines for balanced and informative reviews.

The review fails to provide specific details about what made the service "poor" or why the noodles were unsatisfactory. Generalized complaints without context are less helpful to other users and may not meet Google's standards for relevance.

review_text:
Very disappointing....

It took us almost 3 hours for waiting time; scanned the QR code at 12nn and was able to sit down at 3pm.

I can see the effort of making the chicken broth, a lot of chicken feet and plenty of roasted chicken. The sous vide chicken breast is tender and nicely flavoured.

HOWEVER, as a Japanese ramen, noodles is the most important element. The noodles was over-cooked, very soft and soggy. The chef was too busy and simply left the noodles in the sieve before the sides are ready. The noodles was once over-cooked and stick together in the sieve.

I feel like they want to make something advanced and fusion with western style or even french style. However, please do the best basic practise before implementing your new ideas.

Came here a multiple times these past years. Expect at least 2 hours wait after scanning the qr code, and 30 minutes after receiving the sms, which is disrespectful for the client. The ramens are good and the restaurant is beautiful from the inside. The staff is overloaded, so you'll need to call them multiple times to get service, they also make a lot of mistakes. I don't recommend it, it's just a hyped restaurant with a bad service. I don't understand the people who put 5 stars.
Worst restaurant ever. Waited for the ramen for 40 mins. Reminded twice. Asked for simply a small for four times to get one. The worst service in the world.

Very mixed feelings.. I am still thinking if the food was that delicious or it was placebo effect from the fact of Michelin.. nevertheless even if food would be outstanding, the service and entire booking, waiting experience just degrading everything. I was literally thinking to put one star. Over hyped place. Waiting time 90+ minutes on some waiting list, then in the range of 6-30 minutes it has been cancelled and we've got a SMS to come within 10 minutes other wise our reservation will be cancelled..then another 15 minutes to just order (not mentioning we have been sitting next to the doors behind some rickshaw, which isn't even table for two..), water what we asked for they didn't even bring, then asked twice to pay..I do believe you can find similar food with definitely better service.. This has far far from Michelin experience.

What Michelin have seen, that I didn‚Äôt see? Why so hyped up? First of all the food is average, you can have the same ramen from a typical restaurant through Uber eats, the food is not that great. The eggs aren‚Äôt good, and i think not also 48h marinated, the yolks were also overcooked. The ramen wasn‚Äôt umami also. Secondly, the space isn‚Äôt clean, and be careful for broken ramen bowls and broken porcelain spoons. The worst is the queue front of the restaurant and the way the staff  managed it. We‚Äôre waiting for more than 1.30 hours and we‚Äôre people that passing us and had registered after us. If you love ramen don‚Äôt waist your time their, if you‚Äôre following the hype and you love sceneries, props and you need a good Instagram‚Äôs story is your place.
Really disappointed with the time I spent:(

Waiting time was 3 hours so we thought it will be something special; it wasn‚Äôt . I know you can‚Äôt expect much but English wasn‚Äôt theirs strong side not to mention that our group was able to speak Czech, Italian, Spanish, English and we still didn‚Äôt get what we ordered. Additionally to the wrongly ordered items we were told that we ate it and that‚Äôs why we need to pay what they charged us. On top of all I appreciate when Japanese Ramen joint offer Kaedama, but not when you order through half of your meal and then you wait another 20 minutes and ask twice for extra noodles when your ramen is cold by the time of getting extra order.

I was lucky enough to pop up in a moment where there were basically no one, the restaurant being completely empty except for 1-2 other customers. Horrible welcome forcing me to sit in the smallest back corner just under a sound bar with loud sound of yelling on the market - obviously part of their 'vibe'. Ruined experience from the start..
At one point I wasn't able to stand that anymore when I only wanted a calm solitary lunch. The restaurant was still totally empty, but It was still a huge problem to give me the better place I wanted.. Negotiated a middle solution, but then the waitress started bothering me every 5-10 min in order to assure I'll finish quickly. So I did and left the restaurant as empty as it was when I came..
I think food was delicious, but I don't remember well because of the rest of the experience..
I‚Äôve been waiting so long for my meal. The dining environment is good but crowded. The water cup is not clean. For taste, I had a classic ramen and it was just average at all.

Waited in line 30 minutes before the restaurant opened to be told to scan a QR code and reserve a spot. Scan the code and was told 85-110 minute wait. After 90 minutes, we were told 35-50 minutes. 5 minutes later we get a message that our table is ready and we have 10 minutes to arrive. We run to the restaurant and get there in 8 minutes. We check-in and are told we are next. At least 3 other parties were sat and then we were allowed in (another 20 minutes). We are crammed on a corner of a bar and given a menu. 15 minutes later were are able to order. We ask for 2 entr√©es and 2 ramen, which were were told to upgrade to the chef's edition for a "beautiful experience". Ok we upgrade. We receive 1 entr√©e and 2 ramen. The food was bland. It is quickly made and tastes like powdered ramen from the grocery store. The staff cannot handle a full restaurant much less a crowded one. I have no idea how this made the Michelin list. Very disappointed. Would not recommend.
Reason:
This review fails to comply with Google's policies due to:
- Speculation Without Evidence: Claims about food quality and Michelin recognition are speculative and lack substantiation.
- Excessive Negativity Without Balance: The review focuses entirely on negative aspects without acknowledging any redeeming qualities or providing constructive feedback.
- Irrelevant Content: Details about running to the restaurant or being crammed at a bar are not directly relevant to assessing the dining experience.
- Harmful Language: Overly harsh comparisons (e.g., powdered ramen) are potentially defamatory and violate Google's prohibition on harmful content.

review_text:
The ramens did not taste authentic - the soup, noodles, ambience, and services were below the Japanese standards. It might be good for tourists as an attraction. It looked odd that people bumping their heads against huge lanterns while eating.
People were packed in small long tables, bumping each other while eating. Not enough place to put personal belongings‚Ä¶ my sons started fighting as their elbows were hitting against each other while eating. It was a nightmare‚Ä¶

Not worth the wait. We waited more than 1 hour. It was my first time to see Shio ramen with 3 slices of Lemon üòÖ.  The chicken toppings are not chashu but they are simply just bland chicken breasts slices.. so sad

Pire service‚Ä¶ On s‚Äôen fout de votre vie de lyc√©ens ! Aucun √©thique de travail ‚òπÔ∏è

Worst service I‚Äôve seen. Servers gather together right behind my back and chatting super loud. They prefer hanging out with their friends at their workplace, rather than serving the real customers. I highly recommend Kodawari Tsukiji in the 1st arrondissement which is way better in every aspect.

Gearing up for a backlash of comments in this one; Tiktokers and many google reviewers tout this as the ‚Äúbest ramen in Paris‚Äù, but that‚Äôs if you‚Äôve never had proper Japanese ramen. What‚Äôs more, we queued up almost 2 hours for disappointment.

Atmosphere was great; interior is made to look like Tokyo streets and they even had urban Tokyo soundscapes playing in the background. We ordered a tori-don starter, a Chef‚Äôs Paitan and a Chef‚Äôs Kurogoma. We were warned about the amount of salt but I think most Europeans think salt and MSG are the same thing. Yes MSG gives that unique taste to most Asian dishes, especially Japanese ramen, but it was TOO MUCH.

The tori don‚Äôs chicken AND rice was terribly dry. The sauce had a unique yuzu tangy taste to it but the MSG overpowered it.

Both ramen were novel; a black sesame broth and a rich chicken broth with a mix of yuzu. It was both complex, but felt it was complex just for the sake of being complex. Even then, whatever taste that was supposed to emerge from it eventually got masked with MSG.

I‚Äôd give a 1 typically for disappointments, but I‚Äôll give 2 for consolations, like the never-ending patience of the door girl serving everyone, and like how they got the texture of the egg, the noodles and the chashu perfect. But broth is everything in ramen, my friends.

And no, not worth the 2 hour wait.

One of the worst places you can go for. Best to avoid
Unprofessional staff - apparantly they have online reservations but don't expect a table even after their confirmation of table availability. They made us wait till the end because half of their staff has no idea how to handle it. BUT WAIT IF YOU ARE JAPANESE THEN YOU CAN SKIP THE QUEUE.
Now comes the good part, after the poor service and goof upsal at their end and apologies they will let you order BUT here comes the staff with bill right after your first bite and make you pay because their cashier has to go.
Even a small restuarant without Michelin star will ensure a proper service and be thoughtful of bate minimum customer serving etiquettes.

Overall, the place to avoid

We ordered SHOYU RAMEN ‚Äú their classic‚Äù and KUROGOMA RAMEN ‚Äúthe specialty‚Äù.
I swear to god the kurogoma especially was not even for dogs honestly it was unbelievably disgusting, the taste it was pure 100% ash.

Not to mention that the app to sign up for a table said our wait would be 45mins - 1hr and we waited still almost 3 hours to go inside and they forgot to bring us our appetizer.

I really dont understand why it has so many and on average good critics‚Ä¶
I am telling you RUN AWAY I WILL ALWAYS REMEMBER THAT PUREE ASHY TASTE.

I make myself Ramen as home brew cook, and in my opinion they totally killed the taste. I have eaten at many ramen restaurants, but this one was by far the worst.

In Ramen you need to balance each of tastes. Their speciality uses black garlic and its overkill. They forgot my egg and they have only toilet for all the customers.

This bar is overhyped and not worth your time.
Endless line for an average overpriced ramen and bad service

We wanted to go inside and see if there are any table‚Äòs free but before we could step inside the waiter yelled at us we should stay outside. It was very rude, he could have said that in a more friendly way, and we left immediately after that.

Queued virtually and arrived when we were next up. Staff at the entrance told us to go away, just to call us back by notification few seconds later. The Ramen was good, the broth not 100% authentic. Also there was a very strong bad smell in the restaurant.

Good soba noodles. But if you‚Äôre looking for authentic Japanese ramen, definitely not in this restaurant.
Besides, the waitress (on 29Dec 13h35) let two of her friends (just arrived and scanned the QR code) go in without waiting in the queue, while the others at least waited for an hour. Such a fair system! Bravo!!

So, I was insanely excited for this Ramen joint, as I would consider myself somewhat of a Ramen addict. Having lived in Japan, this ramen was not what I was expecting. Waited 40mins to get a table, which is fine, but I was expecting Japanese Ramen style, customers coming in and out. The broth felt light but without depth of flavour and the prices for quantity don‚Äôt match up. I understand if quality is over quantity however quality was lacking too. I had to ask 4 times to pay before someone came to settle bill. Don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll be coming here again.

Really disappointed that when we arrived after an hour and a half of waiting that they don‚Äôt have non-meat options. Quite rude given how simple it is to fulfill that option and how long some of these customers wait for these dishes. As a person of Japanese descent, I feel like the Michelin star needs to be stripped of this place for not being so encompassing of people‚Äôs dietary needs. Some of our drinks orders were not available also. When we asked for the bowl of the ramen without the soap for the vegetarian options they brought it with Parmesan, for a Japanese descent person having a bowl of Parmesan ramen is an abomination and a DECEPTION. IM APPALLED BY THIS MICHELIN STAR RESTAURANT.

Seating is REALLY cramped, and it had a large negative impact on the dining experience. My knees were pressed against a ribbed counter since I had to leave room for the queue behind me. The long queue behind me was people lining up to pay after their meal.

The ramen itself was decent, the beef was cut too thick for my taste though, and was not tender at all. The broth was tasty, and so were the noodles. Presentation was nice too.

The lady calling out names to go in the restaurant was not helping us, the tourists, in getting lined up for the food. Both my husband and I have scanned the QR code and registered for the line up but never received any text on our turn after having waited for over an 1 hour. We kept asking the lady have we successfully registered the queuing as we hadn‚Äôt received any text but was rudely told to just scan and wait for the text on our turn. Right before we gave up and left, we were told by a patron that there is something wrong with the QR code system with tourists and manual registration is hence required, and the lady didn‚Äôt bother to tell us from the beginning and make us waited. This is a disappointing experience

I was expecting more of the shoyu ramen. Coming from someone who eats a lot of ramen around different cities, having salad, a tomato and some diced apples in a ramen is a big nono.

Broth was way too strong and had a weird aftertaste, and egg didn't taste much.
If this is the best from paris, I wouldn't recommend going.

Authentic interior, good atmosphere, but the worst ramen ever in my life.  2 thin slices meat, too much soy sauce in completely non-rich broth. I took the best frame from the chef.  2 for atmosphere, for ramen 0

Wish I could give it a 0. Went because of the rating - the food was fine, but the serving staff(at least the ones serving when I was there) were so extremely pushy to the point of being plain rude. Let people order what they want and eat it in peace!

I was in and out within 15 minutes when the restaurant was at best 50% occupied, so I saw no reason to be so incessant in coming up to the table again and again.

Okay ramen, not worth the wait.
I‚Äôve had lots of authentic ramen experiences before, this is just ‚Äúalright‚Äù at best, don‚Äôt understand why people are saying this is the best you can get in Europe because it definitely isn‚Äôt.

On the other hand, the virtual queuing system was a joke. We went on a Sunday at like 5pm, busy as hell but google showed it as ‚Äúnot very busy‚Äù. Staff even went as far as saying to everyone waiting: ‚Äúthe more I see you (in front of the store) the less I‚Äôm likely to call you in because you shouldn‚Äôt be here.‚Äù They also told us that the time or place shown on the virtual queuing system didn‚Äôt matter. Waited for a while but then we left because we had their ramen before and it‚Äôs really not all that.

The system makes no sense. People who left and got called several times without them being present could still get in after getting called like three times, never mind the people behind them in the system.

More of a ‚Äúif-you‚Äôre-lucky-enough-to-get-in-you-might-like-it‚Äù kind of place. Not going back because my time is worth more.

I was told this is the best ramen in the world. I can guess so based on the popularity of the place. However, I decided to give this place one star only: There is unorganized crowd in front of restaurant. When I asked how it works, I was told to scan QR code and get into virtual waiting list. It sounds like 21. century until you try it. The page accepted me into queue and asked me to click button to get information on queue and waiting time. Then it was infinitely loading, downloading Skeepit app didnt help as I was receiving error that there is issue with server connection, when I came back to web page it was again asking me to fill form. I managed to get through crowd to employee and he got information from his phone: my waiting time is estimated to 3,5 hours.

That can be the best Ramen in Paris, but I am not sure this user experience is worth it. Sometimes old school queue in front of restaurant is better than clumsy virtual queue in app (and I really like the idea that you can stroll through neighborhood while waiting, it just didnt work).

We went there with my friends for lunch. It was a nice place, but crowded. Few hours after our lunch my friends had a stomach ache... Then me...  We discover that we all have food poisoning... It gave us a nice day üòµ‚Äçüí´ too bad it wasn't my first time there but it was my first time getting sick after eating there.

Slow service, hardcore concept with unattentive service, lacking spoons, "burnt" dashi, bland rare, chasu undercooked and overly fatty, so it overshadowed chicken fat.

Not good.

And after waiting 16 minutes for a spoon for ramen, and 21 minutes subsequently after they took a wrong order, they asked for tips....

Stay away

This place is very, very over-evaluated!  Perhaps for students on a budget, this is a place to become an experience - the slums of Japan as the attendants idly try to put on a theatrical performance.  8.10.21, 15:40 - Ramen soup, we asked for a classic, branded one.  but, they brought us a tasteless slurry with noodles, one thin piece of bacon and an egg, salted.
As if the water had been swallowed with soy sauce.
We also drank 2 lemonades and water.
We couldn't eat it, left the dish intact, but the staff didn't ask why we didn't eat. We are disappointed, they don't know how to cook this soup here.
Oh, yes, if we stood in line for 40 minutes, as they say in the reviews ... we would not be able to survive this disappointment.
It‚Äôs a pity for a wasted time!

The logic here is so terrible. I go alone and have to wait more than 2 hours. I have to continue waiting, even when the system informed that I have seat. The people who are at the same time have the table before one hour. Finally, I have the table at the same time with the guy waiting just haft an hour. I have try to explain and ask to combine with another people but the waitress just ignore. It wasted a day with this bad experience.

We had to wait for an hour which was ok, however after this wait the man refused to let in cause all parties must arrive, we reserved a table for 6, 5 of us arrived but the man refused to let us in ( cause he said all parties must arrive) i asked him nicely if he can let us in cause i wanted my senior parents to be seated  and told him the 6th person in less then 10 minutes away, he didn‚Äôt had sympathy for my senior parents). After all this also they mistakenly didn‚Äôt get our order wrong and the food was regular. Either was it was a new experience but wouldn‚Äôt recommend it

What's great: the design, the friendly staff
What's not so great: ramens are so so.
Salt water ramen. It‚Äôs overrated. Staff is super nice though.

Really good the first Time and second Time amazing, the queue was worth it ,2/3 years ago.
Last Time we went this december 2021 i found it good but strange to find a tomatoe and rocket in my ramen, not japanese test anymore, tables are really closed to eachother even with covid and we needed to change table because they placed us next to the dishing room with door closing and opening ALL the time plus some flies around

review_text:
Short version: largely overrated, tasteless and yet senselesly salty, light years away from being the best in France or in Europe as some earlier reviews suggested. Do not waste your time queuing for it. It's a trap for tourists and people who don't know much about ramen cuisine.

Long version: I have been to Japan 5 times in many cities, have lived in Asia for 30+ years and 10+ years in Europe and tried countless ramen restaurants. So I consider myself a good authority in rating ramen restaurants.

I had high expectations for Kodawari, as many earlier reviews acclaimed the restaurant to be the best in France / Europe. If you have time and are a real ramen fan, I suggest you take a trip to Toulouse, it's much more worth it.

My impression about Kodawari:
1. The noodles: they were undercooked and therefore failed to absorb the taste of the broth, making the noodles taste like cardboard paper. The noodle type they use (Á¥∞„Å£È∫∫) usually (when cooked right) goes well with chicken broth, and yet it was ruined in amateur's hands.

2. The broth: I ordered two different flavors just to do a fair review to the restaurant, one was shoyu ramen with chicken broth and the other was Kaga miso ramen. Both bowls failed to deliver the height of the original recipes, they had no depth nor layers in taste. The shoyu ramen had a faint hint of chicken taste (almost like the broth had been diluted) and the shoyu taste was almost nonexistent (also, it was like if the broth had been diluted very much and just got MSG to raise the umami taste). I barely finished the shoyu ramen, and I couldn't even take half of the Kaga miso ramen soup, it was simply numbingly salty, like a cheap bowl of instant noodles. It was as if the Kaga miso was mixed with some 2nd-grade cheap miso: it didn't taste like anything of what I know about Kaga miso. Two other customers next to me also ordered the Kaga miso ramen and they also said the same: too salty. To give you an idea how salty it is: it's even saltier than Naritake (another well known Ramen restaurant in Paris).

3. The toppings: the pork chashu had no taste and was just stiff and dry, I assume that the meat was overcooked without time to be properly marinated or seasoned and braised over simmering heat (which is the standard Japanese chashu preparation method). In the Kaga miso ramen, they put a slice of eggplant, which I can't understand why, as it was also tasteless and pasty, the texture like a kitchen towel soaked with tooth paste. Toppings in a bowl of ramen are meant to accompany each slurp of noodles by complementing the taste depth and texture.

Conclusion: if the best Japanese ramen I have tried in Europe rates 10, Kodawari is about 4. Do not fall for Kodawari's pretty interior decoration.

review_text:
Le ramen est d√©licieux et le service est charmant. Je ne recommande pas le chasu poulet, cela a le go√ªt de poulet cuit √† l'eau pendant quelques minutes, rien de sp√©cial.

En ce qui concerne le paiement, je ne comprends pas pourquoi, si vous payez par carte bancaire, le lecteur propose 3 options pour le pourboire (vous pouvez choisir de ne pas laisser de pourboire, mais l'affichage de cet √©cran cr√©e une pression sur le client).

Nous ne sommes pas aux √âtats-Unis, je ne pense pas que cela soit appropri√©. De plus, j'ai mang√© dans plusieurs restaurants japonais aux √âtats-Unis, et ils ne demandent jamais de pourboire. Ayant travaill√© dans un restaurant japonais auparavant, il est toujours inappropri√© pour un employ√© d'accepter un pourboire, il doit le refuser.

En fait, si vous connaissez la culture japonaise, le pourboire est en fait une insulte. Je ne doute pas de l'authenticit√©, car les employ√©s se comportent comme dans d'autres entreprises japonaises, mais en affichant l'√©cran de pourboire, le patron force les clients √† envisager de laisser un pourboire. De plus, le pourboire est pertinent dans un restaurant qui offre un service compl√©mentaire, ce qui n'est pas le cas pour le restaurant de ramen.
Reason:
PARTIEL (0.99): The reviewer states, "En fait, si vous connaissez la culture japonaise, le pourboire est en fait une insulte," suggesting that tipping contradicts Japanese cultural norms. While tipping may not be customary in Japan, this claim generalizes cultural practices and imposes them on a restaurant operating in France, where tipping is more common. This speculative statement could mislead users into believing the restaurant's practices are inappropriate or disrespectful without considering the local context. Kodawari Ramen operates within a French context where tipping is an accepted practice, even if not mandatory. Criticizing this adaptation reflects cultural bias rather than evaluating the restaurant fairly based on its location.

The assertion that "le patron force les clients √† envisager de laisser un pourboire" due to the payment terminal displaying tipping options is subjective. The system allows users to opt out of tipping, which does not constitute coercion or force. This exaggeration misrepresents the situation and violates Google's guidelines for truthful and balanced reviews.
